presentation.title: Analyzing Facebook's Impact on Mental Health

content.title: Introduction to Social Media Impact
content.body: Examine Facebook's impact on student mental health using a quasi-experiment, focusing on depression-related treatments, its effects, and revealing compelling connections.

content.title: Understanding Mental Health Concerns
content.description: Exploring the link between social media and mental health, highlighting depression, anxiety, intervention importance, and Facebook's role. Emphasizes comprehensive mental health impact assessments.

body.heading: Focus Areas
body.description: Examining potential impacts on depression and anxiety symptoms.

body.heading: Intervention Timing
body.description: Utilizing Facebook's staggered introduction across colleges for analysis.

body.heading: Comprehensive Effects
body.description: Highlighting significant findings on mental health interventions.

content.title: History of Facebook's College Expansion
content.description: An exploration of Facebook's initial rollout beginning with Harvard in **2004** and its rapid expansion to **300 colleges** within two years, examining mental health implications.

body.heading: Initial Rollout
body.description: Began at Harvard in **2004**.

body.heading: Expansion Pace
body.description: Reached **300 colleges** in two years.

body.heading: Mental Health Implications
body.description: Unique opportunity to study effects on student well-being.

content.title: Quasi-Experimental Study Design
content.description: Utilizes Facebook's college launch and the NCHA survey's comprehensive data to rigorously study mental health shifts through a DD framework. Includes college and survey-wave fixed effects.

body.heading: Staggered Introduction
body.description: Method leverages Facebook's college launch for impact analysis.

body.heading: NCHA Survey
body.description: Comprehensive data source on student health behaviors and events.

body.heading: DD Framework
body.description: Includes college and survey-wave fixed effects for robust findings.

content.title: Mental Health Effects of Facebook
content.description: Facebook's introduction led to increased depression-related service use and poor mental health symptoms (**0.085 SD**). These are detailed with strong service impact over symptoms.

infographics.title: Percentage Change in Service Use
infographics.description: Shows a **5%** increase in depression-related service usage.

infographics.title: Standard Deviation Increase
infographics.description: Illustrates a **0.085** SD rise in poor mental health symptoms.

body.heading: Mental Illness Susceptibility
body.description: Linked to greater adverse impacts from Facebook use.

body.heading: LASSO Framework Use
body.description: Analyzed data from multiple colleges over different periods.

body.heading: Policy Implications
body.description: Effective interventions could focus on high-risk student populations.

body.heading: Survey Data
body.description: Findings based on comprehensive survey data analysis.

content.title: Exposure Duration and Mental Health
content.description: Facebook's impact on mental health grows with exposure, showing a **0.12 SD** increase after five semesters. Emphasizes the need for understanding social media's long-term effects on students.

infographics.title: Length of Facebook Exposure Impact
infographics.description: A **0.12 SD** increase in poor mental health symptoms.

content.title: Ensuring Robustness of Findings
content.description: Comprehensive robustness checks using placebo tests, multi-testing adjustments, and bias assessments confirm Facebook's significant impact on mental health across varying contexts.

body.heading: Placebo Tests
body.description: Used to verify causal relationships.

body.heading: Multi-Testing Adjustments
body.description: Ensures results are not due to chance.

body.heading: Bias Assessments
body.description: Analyzes potential biases in treatment and control groups.

content.title: Negative Academic Consequences
content.body: Analyzing mental health impacts on academic performance post-Facebook, focusing on depression's effect, reduced grades, and engagement in activities. Data from Salk's research supports findings.

body.heading: Negative Social Comparisons
body.description: Adverse impacts on mental health and behavior.

body.description: Perceptions of peer activities and drinking habits.

body.description: Increased social pressure and behavioral changes.
